revision.comment: minor fixes, replaced: 888 - 195 → 888–195 (2), location=Adelaide, SA → location=Adelaide, newspaper=[[Barrier Miner|Barrier Miner (Broken Hill, NSW : 1888–1954)] → newspaper=[[The Barrier Miner]], newspaper=[[The using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict| conflict=Ruck Family Massacre| image=| caption=| partof=[[Mau Mau Uprising]]| date=January 1953| place=[[Great Rift Valley, Kenya|Rift Valley]], [[Kenya]]| result=| combatant1={{flag|United Kingdom}}| combatant2=[[Mau Mau]]| commander1=| commander2=| strength1=3 Europeans
1 African Servant| strength2=30| casualties1=4 killed| casualties2=| }} {{Campaignbox Mau Mau Uprising}} '''The Ruck Family Massacre''' took place during the [[Mau Mau Uprising]]. Farmer Roger Ruck, his wife Esme and six-year-old son Michael, along with their African servants, were massacred by Mau Mau.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1375967/Kenya-Mau-Mau-atrocities-1950s-dossier.html Tony Rennell, "Justifiably the British are accused of brutality in 1950s Kenya. But why aren't the Mau Mau butchers also in the dock?", ''Daily Mail'', 12 April 2011] accessed 9 November 2013 The massacre shocked the European community in Kenya and led to 1,500 European settlers marching on the Governor demanding action.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49251428 |title=MAU TERRORISTS MURDER FAMILY. |newspaper=[[The Barrier Miner]] |location=Broken Hill, NSW |date=27 January 1953 |accessdate=9 November 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47525510 |title=30 Africans Held In Killer Hunt. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=27 January 1953 |accessdate=9 November 2013 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The massacre was fictionalised in the novel ''[[Something of Value]]'' by [[Robert Ruark]], and in the 1957 film version. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:History of Kenya]] [[Category:Mau Mau Uprising]]
